article.headline: Air Force 71, Colorado State 56
article.story: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo. (AP) -- Jacob Burtschi knew he was up against Colorado State's 7-foot phenom -- and knew, too, how to capitalize on his home court. Burtschi scored 21 points Wednesday night -- much of those while being guarded by the 6-inch taller Jason Smith -- to help the Air Force Falcons (18-3, 6-2 Mountain West Conference) remain undefeated at home this season with a 71-56 win over the Rams (12-9, 1-7). "Nothing against 7-footers, but I mean I'm a little bit quicker," Burtschi said. "It just helps me out because if they lay off, I'm going to take the 3, if they get on me, I'm going to drive." By exploiting the improbable mismatch, Burtschi scored 15 of his points in a mostly lethargic first half for the Falcons, when they struggled to keep pace with the hungry Rams for most of the period. "We kind of came out a little slow, a little sluggish," Antoine Hood said. But the Falcons settled down, ending the half with a 10-0 run that gave them a 37-28 halftime lead. Hood scored five of those points, his first of the game. "The run helped us out," Burtschi said. "We picked up the energy, we just started knocking down our shots and playing better defense." The run also re-energized Air Force's home crowd, giving them the advantage Colorado State has failed to overcome since the 2001-02 season -- the last time the Rams beat Air Force in Clune Arena. The Falcons have won 14 straight at home, dating back to last February. "When you can't hear what you're saying because the crowd's so loud, it does make a difference," said Air Force's Matt McCraw, who finished with 11 points. "Our crowd really helped us out tonight." Hood added 15 points and Dan Nwaelele scored 14 for the Falcons, who handed in-state rival CSU its fifth straight loss and 20th consecutive defeat on the road against a Mountain West Conference opponent. Smith led CSU with 27 points and seven rebounds, but the team never fully capitalized on its height advantage inside against Air Force's zone defense. Stephan Gilling added 11 points for Colorado State. "It was frustrating the way we attacked their zone," Smith said. "We had to react better to it." The Falcons continued to pull away early in the second half, with Burtschi, McCraw and Keith Maren all making 3-pointers to give Air Force a 57-36 lead with 12:14 remaining. The Falcons finished 8-for-20 from beyond the arc and shot 60 percent from the floor for the game. Meanwhile, the Rams went cold, shooting 42.9 percent and more than doubling their turnovers in the second half. At one point, CSU went almost 4½ minutes without a field goal, before Smith dunked and hit a free throw to make it 61-43 with 5:50 remaining. "We didn't knock (shots) down the rest of the game," CSU coach Dale Layer said. "You have to counter their 3s with 3s, and we didn't." Air Force center John Frye missed almost all the first half after cutting his forehead on the floor while trying to snag a rebound. He got nine stitches above his right eye, but failed to score after he returned.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
